facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 178 of 1957 was filed by special leave in the Supreme Court.

Pandey, Special Magistrate at Nagpur in Criminal Case No. I of 1955.

facts.text: Nagpur High Court passed order dated May 28, 1956 in Criminal Revision No. 150 of 1956.

facts.text: Special Magistrate Shri K. L. Pandey at Nagpur passed order dated February 2, 1956 in Criminal Case No. I of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Revision No. 150 of 1956 arising out of the order dated February 2, 1956, of Shri K. L. Pandey, Special Magistrate at Nagpur in Criminal Case No. I of 1955. Patnaik, for the appellant. N. Bindra and R. H. Dhebar, for the respondent.

facts.text: Judgment of the Supreme Court was delivered on May 22, 1958 by KAPUR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. May 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Nagpur companyfirming the decision of the Special Magistrate disallowing the application of the appellant to give evidence as a witness under s. 342A of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: Nagpur High Court confirmed the decision of the Special Magistrate disallowing the appellant's application to give evidence under s. 342A of the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Nagpur companyfirming the decision of the Special Magistrate disallowing the application of the appellant to give evidence as a witness under s. 342A of the Criminal Procedure Code. The Advocate-General of Madhya Pradesh, on January 13, 1953, filed a companyplaint against the appellant and three others under s. 282 of the Indian Companies Act and ss. 465 and 477A of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The Advocate-General of Madhya Pradesh, on January 13, 1953, filed a companyplaint against the appellant and three others under s. 282 of the Indian Companies Act and ss. 465 and 477A of the Indian Penal Code. facts.text: Criminal Procedure Code Amendment Act 26 of 1955 received assent of the President on August 12, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On August 12, 1955, the Criminal Procedure Code  Amendment  Act  26 of 1955  received the assent of the President and came into force on January 2, 1956. In this judgment it will be referred to as the Amending Act and the Code of Criminal Procedure as the Code. On January 14, 1956, the appellant made an application to the Magistrate claiming the right to appear as a witness on his own behalf under s. 342A of the amended Code in disproof of the charges made against him . His application was dismissed and so was his revision to the High Court of Nagpur which held While it must be companyceded that the wording of clause  c  as also the other clauses of section 116 of the amending Act companyld have been put in simpler and more direct language, its ingenuous circumlocution cannot be allowed to cloak.

facts.text: Criminal Procedure Code Amendment Act 26 of 1955 came into force on January 2, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: received the assent of the President and came into force on January 2, 1956. In this judgment it will be referred to as the Amending Act and the Code of Criminal Procedure as the Code. On January 14, 1956, the appellant made an application to the Magistrate claiming the right to appear as a witness on his own behalf under s. 342A of the amended Code in disproof of the charges made against him . His application was dismissed and so was his revision to the High Court of Nagpur which held While it must be companyceded that the wording of clause  c  as also the other clauses of section 116 of the amending Act companyld have been put in simpler and more direct language, its ingenuous circumlocution cannot be allowed to cloak. its true meaning or to permit the companystruction which the applicant seeks to put upon it.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that s. 342A of the amended Code is available to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion on the plain companystruction of the words used in s. 116 of the amending Act, s. 342A available to the appellant. The High Court, it appears, was misled into companystruing the words in clause  c  of s. 116 i. e. as if this Act had number been passed. The High Court was therefore in error and the appellant is entitled, in our view, as a companypetent witness for the defence to testify in disproof of the charges made against him or any other person charged together with him at the same trial.

anchor.surface_text: According to the provisions of the unamended Code an accused person could not appear as a witness in his defence although for the purpose of enabling him to explain circumstances appearing in the evidence against him the Court could put such questions as it considered necessary. Section 118 of the Evidence Act deals with persons who are competent to testify as witnesses but in view of s. 342 of the unamended Code no accused person could appear as a witness and therefore s. 118 was inapplicable to such persons.

anchor.surface_text: There is no controversy on the general principles applicable to the case. No person has a vested right in any course of procedure. He has only the right of prosecution or defence in the manner prescribed for the time being by or for the Court in which the case is pending and if by an Act of Parliament the mode of procedure is altered he has no other right than to proceed according to the altered mode.

It provides- S. 251 In the trial of warrant cases by Magistrates,the Magistrate shall,- a in any case instituted on a police report, follow the procedure specified in section 251A and b in any other case, follow the procedure specified in the other provisions of this Chapter.

issues.text: whether to a pending prosecution the provisions of the amended Code have become applicable

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for decision is whether to a pending prosecution the provisions of the amended Code have become applicable. There is no controversy on the general principles applicable to the case.

issues.text: whether the words in clause (c) of s. 116 'and every such inquiry or trial shall be continued and disposed of as if this Act had not been passed' mean that no provision of the Act would be applicable to pending trials

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the respondent that the following words in clause c of s. 116 of the amending Act and every such enquiry or trial shall be continued and disposed of as if this Act had not been passed mean that no provision of the Act would be applicable to pending trials and particular stress was laid on the words as if this Act had not been passed.

issues.text: whether s. 342A of the amended Code is applicable to an inquiry or trial before a Magistrate in which the Magistrate has begun to record evidence prior to the date of commencement of the amending Act

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion on the plain construction of the words used in s. 116 of the amending Act, s. 342A [is] available to the appellant.

arguments.claim: The wording of clause (c) and other clauses of section 116 of the amending Act does not permit the construction that 'this Act' means only some provisions; proceedings must continue as if the Act had not been passed, so s.342A does not apply

anchor.surface_text: While it must be conceded that the wording of clause  c  as also the other clauses of section 116 of the amending Act could have been put in simpler and more direct language, its ingenuous circumlocution cannot be allowed to cloak. its true meaning or to permit the construction which the applicant seeks to put upon it. The language used doe,-, not justify hold ing that when the statute says this Act it means only some of the provisions of this Act Thus the High Court was of the opinion that the proceedings pending before the Special Magistrate would be according to the procedure laid down in the unamended Code and the appellant could not therefore appear as a witness under s. 342A of the amended Code.

arguments.court_reasoning: Plain construction of s.116; only specified provisions excluded; harmonious reading avoids conflict between clauses and main section

arguments.claim: No person has a vested right in procedure; changes in procedural law apply retrospectively to pending cases unless excluded

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for decision is whether to a pending prosecution the provisions of the amended Code have become applicable. There is no controversy on the general principles applicable to the case. No person has a vested right in any course of procedure. He has only the right of prosecution or defence in the manner prescribed for the time being by or for the Court in which the case is pending and if by an Act of Parliament the mode of procedure is altered he has no other right than to proceed according to the altered mode.

arguments.claim: Except as provided in clauses (a)-(d), all provisions of the amending Act apply to pending proceedings

anchor.surface_text: If that is the interpretation to be put then it would be in conflict with the last portion of the section i. e. Save as aforesaid the provisions of this Act and the amendments made thereby shall apply to all proceedings instituted after the commencement of this Act and also to all proceedings pending in any Criminal Court on the date of such commencement.

arguments.claim: Construing s.116 as excluding all provisions leads to conflict between clauses and main section; interpret to avoid conflict

anchor.surface_text: If the whole section is construed in the manner contended for by the respondent then there will be a conflict between the words used in the various clauses and words used in the main s. 116 and it is one of the principles of interpretation that the words should be construed in such a manner as to avoid a conflict.

arguments.claim: s.342A not excluded by s.116(c) as it is not among ss.4(w),207A,251A,260; in Chapter XXIV, unaffected by Chapter XXI procedures

anchor.surface_text: Thus construed the words of cl.  c  and the words of the rest of the s. 116 would mean this that the provisions of ss. 4  w , 207A, 251A or 260 of the Code as amended shall not apply or affect any enquiry or trial before a Magistrate where the recording of evidence has started prior to the date of the commencement of the amending Act and every such enquiry should be continued and disposed of as if these sections had not been enacted. Except as to this and except as to the provisions mentioned in sub-cls.  a ,  b  and  d  the other provisions of the amended Code would be applicable to such proceedings which is also in accordance with the general principles applicable to amendments in procedural law. By s. 34 of the amending Act, s. 251 of the Code was substituted by two sections i. e. 251 and 251A. Section 251 lays down the procedure in warrant cases.

arguments.claim: s.342A is available to the appellant in this pending trial

anchor.surface_text: Section 251 lays down the procedure in warrant cases. It provides- S. 251 In the trial of warrant cases by Magistrates,the Magistrate shall,- a in any case instituted on a police report, follow the procedure specified in section 251A and b in any other case, follow the procedure specified in the other provisions of this Chapter. Sub-clause a deals with cases instituted on a police report and sub-cl. b with other cases. To the former s. 251A is applicable and to other cases procedure specified in other provisions in Chapter 21 is made applicable. Section 342A is in Chapter 24 and there is nothing in the amending Act or the amended Code which makes the provision of s. 342A inapplicable to criminal proceedings- which are pending before a Magistrate and in which the recording of evidence has commenced. In our opinion on the plain construction of the words used in s. 116 of the amending Act, s. 342A available to the appellant.

holdings.text: No person has a vested right in any course of procedure and procedural amendments apply retrospectively to pending proceedings unless expressly excluded.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for decision is whether to a pending prosecution the provisions of the amended Code have become applicable. There is no controversy on the general principles applicable to the case. No person has a vested right in any course of procedure. He has only the right of prosecution or defence in the manner prescribed for the time being by or for the Court in which the case is pending and if by an Act of Parliament the mode of procedure is altered he has no other right than to proceed according to the altered mode. See Maxwell on Interpretation of Statutes on p. 225 The Colonial Sugar Refining Co. Ltd. v. Irving

holdings.reasoning_summary: No controversy on general principles; cites Maxwell and Colonial Sugar Refining Co. case; procedural law changes operate retrospectively unlike substantive vested rights.

holdings.text: The words in clause (c) of s.116 'every such inquiry or trial shall be continued and disposed of as if this Act had not been passed' refer only to the specifically excluded provisions in clauses (a)-(d), not the entire Act; other provisions apply to pending proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: If that is the interpretation to be put then it would be in conflict with the last portion of the section i. e. Save as aforesaid the provisions of this Act and the amendments made thereby shall apply to all proceedings instituted after the commencement of this Act and also to all proceedings pending in any Criminal Court on the date of such commencement. The language used in this portion of the section in regard to the proceedings which are instituted after the commencement of the amended Code is identical with that dealing with -proceedings pending in a Criminal Court on the date of its commencement. Therefore if this Act applies to all proceedings which commenced after the Act came into force they would equally apply to proceedings which had already commenced except those provisions which have been expressly excluded. If the whole section is construed in the manner contended for by the respondent then there will be a conflict between the words used in the various clauses and words used in the main s. 116 and it is one of the principles of interpretation that the words should be construed in such a manner as to avoid a conflict.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent's broad interpretation conflicts with saving clause and identical language for instituted/pending proceedings; harmonious construction avoids internal conflict.

holdings.text: The provisions of ss.4(w), 207A, 251A, 260 do not apply to inquiries/trials where Magistrate began recording evidence before commencement, but such proceedings continue as if those sections not enacted; other provisions of amended Code apply.

anchor.surface_text: Thus construed the words of cl. c and the words of the rest of the s. 116 would mean this that the provisions of ss. 4 w , 207A, 251A or 260 of the Code as amended shall not apply or affect any enquiry or trial before a Magistrate where the recording of evidence has started prior to the date of the commencement of the amending Act and every such enquiry should be continued and disposed of as if these sections had not been enacted. Except as to this and except as to the provisions mentioned in sub-cls. a , b and d the other provisions of the amended Code would be applicable to such proceedings which is also in accordance with the general principles applicable to amendments in procedural law. By s. 34 of the amending Act, s. 251 of the Code was substituted by two sections i. e. 251 and 251A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual reading of s.116 clauses limited to named provisions; consistent with procedural retrospectivity principles.

holdings.text: s.342A applies to pending proceedings before Magistrate where evidence recording commenced prior to amendment as it is in Chapter XXIV, not among excluded provisions, and nothing renders it inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: Section 251 lays down the procedure in warrant cases. It provides- S. 251 In the trial of warrant cases by Magistrates,the Magistrate shall,- a in any case instituted on a police report, follow the procedure specified in section 251A and b in any other case, follow the procedure specified in the other provisions of this Chapter. Sub-clause a deals with cases instituted on a police report and sub-cl. b with other cases. To the former s. 251A is applicable and to other cases procedure specified in other provisions in Chapter 21 is made applicable. Section 342A is in Chapter 24 and there is nothing in the amending Act or the amended Code which makes the provision of s. 342A inapplicable to criminal proceedings- which are pending before a Magistrate and in which the recording of evidence has commenced.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.342A outside scope of excluded trial procedure sections in Chapters XIX-XXI; no express exclusion.

holdings.text: s.342A is available to the appellant; High Court erred in construing s.116(c); appellant entitled as competent witness for defence.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion on the plain construction of the words used in s. 116 of the amending Act, s. 342A available to the appellant. The High Court, it appears, was misled into construing the words in clause c of s. 116 i. e. as if this Act had not been passed. The High Court was therefore in error and the appellant is entitled, in our view, as a competent witness for the defence to testify in disproof of the charges made against him or any other person charged together with him at the same trial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies plain construction of s.116 to facts; reverses High Court error on scope of clause (c).

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for decision is whether to a pending prosecution the provisions of the amended Code have become applicable. There is no controversy on the general principles applicable to the case. No person has a vested right in any course of procedure. He has only the right of prosecution or defence in the manner prescribed for the time being by or for the Court in which the case is pending and if by an Act of Parliament the mode of procedure is altered he has no other right than to proceed according to the altered mode. See Maxwell on Interpretation of Statutes on p. 225 The Colonial Sugar Refining Co. Ltd. v. Irving
The High Court was therefore in error and the appellant is entitled, in our view, as a companypetent witness for the defence to testify in disproof of the charges made against him or any pe

anchor.surface_text: If that is the interpretation to be put then it would be in conflict with the last portion of the section i. e. Save as aforesaid the provisions of this Act and the amendments made thereby shall apply to all proceedings instituted after the commencement of this Act and also to all proceedings pending in any Criminal Court on the date of such commencement. The language used in this portion of the section in regard to the proceedings which are instituted after the commencement of the amended Code is identical with that dealing with -proceedings pending in a Criminal Court on the date of its commencement. Therefore if this Act applies to all proceedings which commenced after the Act came into force they would equally apply to proceedings which had already commenced except those provisions which have been expressly excluded. If the whole section is construed in the manner contended for by the respondent then there will be a conflict between the words used in the various clauses and words used in the main s. 116 and it is one of the principles of interpretation that the words should be construed in such a manner as to avoid a conflict.
The High Court was therefore in error and the appellant is entitled, in our view, as a companypetent witness for the defence to testify in disproof of the charges made against him or any pe

anchor.surface_text: Thus construed the words of cl. c and the words of the rest of the s. 116 would mean this that the provisions of ss. 4 w , 207A, 251A or 260 of the Code as amended shall not apply or affect any enquiry or trial before a Magistrate where the recording of evidence has started prior to the date of the commencement of the amending Act and every such enquiry should be continued and disposed of as if these sections had not been enacted. Except as to this and except as to the provisions mentioned in sub-cls. a , b and d the other provisions of the amended Code would be applicable to such proceedings which is also in accordance with the general principles applicable to amendments in procedural law. By s. 34 of the amending Act, s. 251 of the Code was substituted by two sections i. e. 251 and 251A.

anchor.surface_text: Section 251 lays down the procedure in warrant cases. It provides- S. 251 In the trial of warrant cases by Magistrates,the Magistrate shall,- a in any case instituted on a police report, follow the procedure specified in section 251A and b in any other case, follow the procedure specified in the other provisions of this Chapter. Sub-clause a deals with cases instituted on a police report and sub-cl. b with other cases. To the former s. 251A is applicable and to other cases procedure specified in other provisions in Chapter 21 is made applicable. Section 342A is in Chapter 24 and there is nothing in the amending Act or the amended Code which makes the provision of s. 342A inapplicable to criminal proceedings- which are pending before a Magistrate and in which the recording of evidence has commenced.
The High Court was therefore in error and the appellant is entitled, in our view, as a companypetent witness for the defence to testify in disproof of the charges made against him or any pe
. 34 of the amending Act, s. 251 of the Code was substituted by two sections i. e. 251 and 251A. Section 251 lays down the procedure in warrant cases.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion on the plain construction of the words used in s. 116 of the amending Act, s. 342A available to the appellant. The High Court, it appears, was misled into construing the words in clause c of s. 116 i. e. as if this Act had not been passed. The High Court was therefore in error and the appellant is entitled, in our view, as a competent witness for the defence to testify in disproof of the charges made against him or any other person charged together with him at the same trial.
